item.title: Israel-Gaza: Rockets pound Israel after militants killed
item.description: Palestinian militants fire a barrage of rockets after some of their commanders die in air strikes.

item.title: Covid: Lessons to be learned from spring 2022 public inquiry - PM
item.description: The state will be "under the microscope", Boris Johnson says, as Labour urges an earlier start date.

item.title: Radovan Karadzic: Ex-Bosnian Serb leader to be sent to UK prison
item.description: The 75-year-old was convicted in 2016 of genocide during the conflict in the former Yugoslavia.

item.title: Blackpool lightning strike: Family tribute to Jordan Banks
item.description: Nine-year-old Jordan Banks was "the brightest star" and "our everything", his family says.

item.title: PM 'apologises for events in Ballymurphy' in 1971
item.description: On Tuesday, an inquest found that 10 people shot in west Belfast in 1971 were innocent.

item.title: On The Beach pulls all summer holidays from sale
item.description: The online travel agent won't be selling summer holidays due to Covid uncertainty.

item.title: Covid: Bolton Indian variant surge leaves hospitality nervous
item.description: Pub and cafe owners in Bolton are apprehensive about reopening amid a rise in the Indian variant.

item.title: No 10 seeks to cancel county court debt judgement against Boris Johnson
item.description: The claim - made against the PM over an alleged unpaid debt of £535 - is without merit, says Downing Street.

item.title: Liz Cheney: Republican ousted from leadership for challenging Trump election claims
item.description: After being removed, Liz Cheney said she would continue to speak out against former President Trump.

item.title: Adoption: 'Our sons' birth family turned them against us'
item.description: There are calls for more support for adoptees - as social media searches for birth families rise.

item.title: Jo Cox: Murdered MP's sister plans to stand in Batley and Spen
item.description: Kim Leadbeater announces her intention to stand for election in Jo Cox's former constituency.

item.title: Calderdale child sexual exploitation: 29 men charged
item.description: Police say the girl was sexually exploited in West Yorkshire between 2003 and 2010.

item.title: Champions League final: Portugal set to host final rather than Wembley
item.description: Portugal is set to host the Champions League final after Uefa failed to receive the guarantees of exemptions it wants if it is to move the game to Wembley.

item.title: Facebook moderator: ‘Every day was a nightmare’
item.description: This is the first time a social media moderator has testified to a parliamentary committee.

item.title: Gemma Arterton: Screen and stage star excited at theatres reopening
item.description: The actress will soon be back on stage in London as theatres reopen with lockdown restrictions easing.

item.title: Ellen DeGeneres to end talk show after 19 years
item.description: "As great as this show is, and as fun as it is, it's just not a challenge any more," she explains.

item.title: Arthur Beale: Sailing goods business closes shop after 500 years
item.description: The Arthur Beale store, which sells specialist marine supplies, says the pandemic has forced its closure.

item.title: In pictures: Commons marks 80 years since WW2 bombing
item.description: Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle commemorates those who died when a Luftwaffe attack destroyed the Commons chamber.

item.title: How did a cyber-attack lead to long queues for petrol in the US?
item.description: How did a cyber attack lead to a shortage of petrol in the US?

item.title: Ajax melt down title trophy to make stars to give fans
item.description: With fans unable to watch in person because of the pandemic, Ajax melt down the Eredivisie trophy to make 42,000 silver stars to thanks fans for their support.

item.title: No sofa, bed, table - people who have to live without furniture
item.description: In the UK more than two million people experience furniture poverty yet it’s rarely spoken about.

item.title: Brit Awards 2021: The best outfits from the red carpet and ceremony
item.description: The stars were out in force at Tuesday night's event, serving up some seriously stylish looks.

item.title: Coronavirus in India: 'My city is under siege from Covid-19'
item.description: The BBC's Vikas Pandey has called Delhi home for more than a decade - but Covid has changed everything.

item.title: Female football fans share experiences of abuse
item.description: Meliza and Kendall are dedicated football fans but say they experience abuse because of their gender.

item.title: Israel-Gaza violence: The strength and limitations of Hamas' arsenal
item.description: The militant group possesses thousands of missiles of varying ranges that it can fire towards Israel.

item.title: Brit Awards 2021: Great show, shame about the videos
item.description: Fans say they loved seeing live music again, but weren't so keen on the pre-taped performances.

item.title: Accessibility and outdoor socialising: 'I feel unwelcome in my own city'
item.description: Pippa Stacey, 26, faces "all kinds of obstacles" as venues sprawl on to pavements.

item.title: Queen's Speech debate: Waiting lists, social care and other claims fact-checked
item.description: Politicians debated the government's plans - set out in the Queen's Speech - and made a series of claims on subjects including hospital waiting lists and social care.

item.title: What are Eid and Ramadan and when are they?
item.description: Ramadan is one of the most important events in the Islamic calendar, but it's been affected by lockdown.

item.title: How Italy's healthcare staff survived the pandemic
item.description: Nurses in Italy have been instrumental in helping to fight Covid-19 - but it's taken a heavy toll.

item.title: Pep Guardiola: How Manchester City boss reinvented Premier League title winners
item.description: Pep Guardiola learned from previous errors to renew his Manchester City side for the better, writes Guillem Balague.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'Master every aspect of your business'
item.description: Windfarm CEO Sarah Merrick says being involved in all areas of her business has paid dividends.

item.title: Budget: Australia tries to win back women with childcare boost
item.description: The government's new budget boosts childcare and women's health, but critics say more reform is needed.

item.title: Israel-Palestinians: Old grievances fuel new fighting
item.description: Failure to tackle deep-seated issues meant fresh violence between the two sides was a matter of time.

item.title: Smith Rowe benefits from Jorginho error as Arsenal win at Chelsea
item.description: Chelsea miss the opportunity to strengthen their place in the top four as Emile Smith Rowe's second Premier League goal in as many games gives Arsenal victory.

item.title: Champions Rangers one game away from unbeaten campaign with Livingston win
item.description: Rangers are one game away from completing an unbeaten Scottish Premiership season after scoring in each half to beat Livingston.

item.title: New signings? Resurgent rivals? What next for Man City after title win?
item.description: Manchester City have reclaimed the Premier League title in style - but where will they strengthen this summer and can they dominate next season?

item.title: F1 clamps down on flexible rear wings after Hamilton's Red Bull claim
item.description: Formula 1's governing body launches a clampdown on flexible rear wings amid suspicions some teams are bending the rules.

item.title: European Aquatics Championships: Great Britain's Jack Laugher wins 1m springboard silver
item.description: Great Britain's Jack Laugher pips Italy's Giovanni Tocci with his final dive to take silver in the men's 1m springboard final at the European Aquatics Championships.

item.title: Covid inquiry: What is it and how will it work?
item.description: An independent public inquiry has been announced, but how will it work?

item.title: Restaurants and pubs are reopening inside, but what are the rules?
item.description: People in England, Scotland and Wales will soon be able to drink inside a pub.

item.title: Covid: What are the social distancing rules and the rule of six?
item.description: Guidance on hugging close friends and family is being relaxed in England and Scotland from 17 May.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Lockdown restrictions will ease in England, Scotland and Wales from Monday 17 May.

item.title: Which countries are on the green list for foreign holidays?
item.description: Scotland is to adopt the same "traffic light" system for foreign travel as England.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Secondary school pupils in England will no longer be required to wear them in class from next week.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 38 and 39 in England are now being offered a Covid vaccine as the rollout continues.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go.... and who with?
item.description: The rules on having a holiday in the UK have been relaxed - but restrictions remain.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does the Covid-19 alert level system work?
item.description: The threat of Covid-19 in England is ranked through a five-level, colour-coded alert system.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 35 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: What is a Covid passport and what are the plans for the NHS app?
item.description: People travelling abroad from England will be able to use the NHS app to prove their Covid vaccination status.

item.title: Covid: What refund rights are there for holidays abroad?
item.description: Quarantine-free overseas holidays will be possible after 17 May, but what rights do you have if plans or rules change?
